news_summary: Astronomers have made exciting discoveries about early cosmic phenomena, capturing a powerful super-eruption from a young sun and identifying a nearby cluster of primordial stars.

articles.title: Astronomers capture a violent super-eruption from a young sun
articles.summary: Astronomers observed a massive, multi-temperature plasma eruption from a young Sun-like star, revealing how early solar explosions could shape planets. These fierce events may have influenced the atmosphere and life-forming chemistry of the early Earth.
articles.content:
Although we rarely notice from Earth, the Sun is continuously hurling enormous clouds of charged plasma into space. These events, known as coronal mass ejections (CMEs), often occur alongside sudden bursts of light called solar flares. When particularly strong, CMEs can stretch far enough to disturb Earth's magnetic field, producing dazzling auroras and sometimes triggering geomagnetic storms that disrupt satellites or even power grids.

Scientists believe that billions of years ago, when the Sun and Earth were both young, solar activity was far more intense than it is today. Powerful CMEs during that period may have influenced the conditions that allowed life to emerge and evolve. Studies of young Sun-like stars -- used as stand-ins for our own star's early years -- show that these stars often unleash flares far stronger than any recorded from the modern Sun.

Reconstructing Ancient Solar Explosions

Massive eruptions from the early Sun likely had dramatic effects on the atmospheres of Earth, Mars, and Venus. Yet researchers still do not fully understand how closely these stellar outbursts resemble today's CMEs. While scientists have recently observed cooler plasma components of CMEs from the ground, detecting the fast-moving, high-energy events expected in the past has proven much more difficult.

To explore this question, an international research team led by Kosuke Namekata of Kyoto University set out to determine whether young Sun-like stars generate CMEs similar to those of our own Sun.

"What inspired us most was the long-standing mystery of how the young Sun's violent activity influenced the nascent Earth," says Namekata. "By combining space- and ground-based facilities across Japan, Korea, and the United States, we were able to reconstruct what may have happened billions of years ago in our own solar system."

The researchers conducted simultaneous ultraviolet observations with the Hubble Space Telescope and optical observations from ground-based telescopes in Japan and Korea. Their subject was the young Sun-like star EK Draconis. Hubble measured ultraviolet light from extremely hot plasma, while the ground-based observatories tracked cooler hydrogen gas through the Hα line. This coordinated, multi-wavelength approach enabled the team to capture both the hot and cool parts of a CME as it unfolded.

Evidence of a Multi-Temperature Solar Eruption

The observations revealed the first-ever evidence of a multi-temperature CME from EK Draconis. The team discovered that plasma heated to about 100,000 degrees Kelvin was expelled at speeds of 300 to 550 kilometers per second (~670,000 to 1,230,000 miles per hour). Roughly ten minutes later, cooler gas around 10,000 degrees was launched at about 70 kilometers per second (~160,000 miles per hour). The high-temperature plasma carried significantly more energy, indicating that frequent and powerful CMEs in the past could have produced strong shocks and energetic particles capable of reshaping or stripping early planetary atmospheres.

Other studies support the idea that energetic solar events and their resulting particles may have triggered chemical reactions that produced biomolecules and greenhouse gases -- key ingredients for sustaining life. This finding therefore deepens our understanding of how solar activity may have created the environmental conditions necessary for life to appear on early Earth, and possibly on other planets as well.

The scientists emphasized that their success depended on global collaboration and precise coordination between space- and ground-based observatories.

"We were happy to see that, although our countries differ, we share the same goal of seeking truth through science," says Namekata.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding the early Sun's violent activity and its impact on planetary atmospheres and the origins of life. This discovery has broad implications for planetary science, astrobiology, and our understanding of conditions necessary for life, benefiting the general public's knowledge of space and life origins. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights international collaboration, making it an inspiring advancement in space science.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers observe powerful solar eruption from young Sun-like star
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Our Sun often sends out huge clouds of charged gas called coronal mass ejections (CMEs), which can affect Earth’s magnetic field and cause bright auroras. Scientists think the young Sun was even more active billions of years ago, possibly shaping the early conditions on Earth and other planets.

**What happened** – A team of researchers from Japan, Korea, and the United States studied a young star similar to the Sun, called EK Draconis. Using the Hubble Space Telescope and ground telescopes, they watched a massive eruption that released both very hot and cooler plasma at high speeds. This was the first time scientists captured this multi-temperature eruption from a young Sun-like star.

**Impact** – The discovery shows that early solar explosions were extremely powerful and could have changed the atmospheres of planets like Earth, Mars, and Venus. These eruptions might have helped create the right chemical ingredients for life by producing important molecules and gases. This helps scientists better understand how life-friendly conditions may have started on Earth.

**What’s next step** – Researchers will continue studying young stars and their eruptions to learn more about how solar activity influences planets. They will use similar combined observations from space and Earth to explore how these violent events affect planetary atmospheres and the possibility of life elsewhere.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By capturing a violent eruption from a young Sun-like star, astronomers gained new insight into how early solar storms may have shaped planets and supported the origins of life.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des astronomes observent une puissante éruption solaire d’une jeune étoile semblable au Soleil
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Notre Soleil envoie souvent de gros nuages de gaz chargé appelés éjections de masse coronale (EMC), qui peuvent affecter le champ magnétique de la Terre et créer de belles aurores. Les scientifiques pensent que le jeune Soleil était encore plus actif il y a des milliards d’années, influençant les conditions sur la Terre et d’autres planètes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe de chercheurs du Japon, de Corée et des États-Unis a étudié une jeune étoile semblable au Soleil, EK Draconis. Grâce au télescope spatial Hubble et à des télescopes au sol, ils ont observé une énorme éruption qui a libéré à la fois du plasma très chaud et plus froid à grande vitesse. C’est la première fois qu’une telle éruption multi-température est capturée sur une étoile jeune.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que les premières explosions solaires étaient très puissantes et pouvaient modifier les atmosphères des planètes comme la Terre, Mars et Vénus. Ces éruptions ont peut-être aidé à créer les ingrédients chimiques nécessaires à la vie en produisant des molécules et des gaz importants. Cela aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre comment les conditions favorables à la vie ont pu commencer sur Terre.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier les jeunes étoiles et leurs éruptions pour mieux comprendre l’influence de l’activité solaire sur les planètes. Ils utiliseront des observations combinées depuis l’espace et la Terre pour explorer comment ces événements violents affectent les atmosphères planétaires et la possibilité de vie ailleurs.

**Une phrase clé** – En capturant une violente éruption d’une jeune étoile semblable au Soleil, les astronomes ont découvert comment les tempêtes solaires anciennes ont pu façonner les planètes et favoriser l’apparition de la vie.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos observan una poderosa erupción solar de una joven estrella similar al Sol
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Nuestro Sol envía a menudo grandes nubes de gas cargado llamadas eyecciones de masa coronal (EMC), que pueden afectar el campo magnético de la Tierra y crear auroras brillantes. Los científicos creen que el joven Sol era aún más activo hace miles de millones de años, influyendo en las condiciones de la Tierra y otros planetas.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de investigadores de Japón, Corea y Estados Unidos estudió una joven estrella parecida al Sol llamada EK Draconis. Usando el telescopio espacial Hubble y telescopios en tierra, observaron una gran erupción que liberó plasma muy caliente y más frío a altas velocidades. Fue la primera vez que capturaron esta erupción con varias temperaturas en una estrella joven.

**Impacto** – El hallazgo muestra que las primeras explosiones solares eran muy poderosas y podían cambiar las atmósferas de planetas como la Tierra, Marte y Venus. Estas erupciones podrían haber ayudado a crear los ingredientes químicos necesarios para la vida al producir moléculas y gases importantes. Esto ayuda a los científicos a entender mejor cómo pudieron comenzar las condiciones para la vida en la Tierra.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán estudiando estrellas jóvenes y sus erupciones para aprender más sobre cómo la actividad solar afecta a los planetas. Usarán observaciones combinadas desde el espacio y la Tierra para explorar cómo estos eventos violentos influyen en las atmósferas planetarias y la posibilidad de vida en otros lugares.

**Una frase clave** – Al capturar una violenta erupción de una joven estrella parecida al Sol, los astrónomos obtuvieron nueva información sobre cómo las tormentas solares antiguas pudieron moldear planetas y apoyar el origen de la vida.

articles.title: We may have found a surprisingly nearby cluster of primordial stars
articles.summary: The very first generation of stars, called Population III stars, are mostly expected to be too distant to see directly – but astronomers may have found some for the very first time
articles.content:
The very first generation of stars, called Population III stars, are mostly expected to be too distant to see directly – but astronomers may have found some for the very first time

Artist’s impression of Population III stars as they would have appeared a 100 million years after the big bang NOIRLab/NSF/AURA/J. da Silva/Spaceengine/M. Zamani

We may have finally seen the first generation of stars. Astronomers have been looking for these primordial behemoths, called Population III stars, for decades. Now they have found what may be the most promising candidate yet.

Population III stars are expected to be very different from modern, or Population I, stars. They would have formed from pristine hydrogen and helium gas, before heavier elements were distributed throughout the universe by supernovae and powerful stellar winds. They are also expected to be bigger and hotter than modern stars.

That is exactly what Eli Visbal at the University of Toledo in Ohio and his colleagues found when they did a detailed analysis of previous James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) observations of a distant galaxy called LAP1-B. It is at a redshift – a number that astronomers use to measure distance – of 6.6, which means we see LAP1-B as it was just about 800 million years after the big bang. That is so far away the only reason we could spot it at all is because its light was magnified by a nearer galaxy cluster in a process called gravitational lensing.

“There should be tons and tons of these all over the observable universe, but we can only look sort of under the lamppost of this cluster that’s magnifying the light,” says Visbal. When he and his team calculated how many Population III star clusters we should find at this redshift, they found that it should be about one – which is what they saw. “Our abundance estimate perfectly agreed with [the previous research team] finding one where they did,” he says.

Another point in LAP1-B’s favour is it only seems to have enough stars to make up a few thousand times the mass of the sun. Other candidates for Population III galaxies tend to have much higher stellar masses, inconsistent with simulations of how clusters of Population III stars form. “This is the best candidate we have so far,” says Visbal.

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

Most Population III stars are expected to have lived and died between about 100 and 400 million years after the big bang, after which there would have been enough heavy elements in the cosmos to form stars that are more similar to the ones we see today. “This object ticks many of the boxes, but I am a bit sceptical because it’s late in the game for these stars to be around, and there may be alternatives that might do the job as well,” says Ralf Klessen at Heidelberg University in Germany. “It would be super interesting to see a Population III star cluster, but statistically this would certainly be an outlier.”

However, it is possible pockets of pristine hydrogen and helium could survive longer and form Population III stars later on, Visbal says.

“LAP-B1 is an extremely interesting candidate, but it is still far from having the clear, unambiguous signatures that we expect for a clean Population III detection,” says Roberto Maiolino at the University of Cambridge. “[For these to be Population III stars], it must be an extremely lucky combination of different factors, each of them extremely rare on its own, and much more rare when they have to happen together.” It will take deeper observations and more detailed simulations to find out for sure if LAP1-B marks the first time we have seen these strange stars.

This is important because understanding Population III stars is crucial to figuring out how and when the first heavy elements formed. “They can tell us how the chemistry of the universe evolved from just hydrogen and helium to all the cool chemistry and life and everything that we have in the universe today,” says Visbal. Population III stars were the first building blocks of the complexity that surrounds us now.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery: the potential first observation of primordial Population III stars, which are crucial to understanding the early universe's chemical evolution. This finding has broad scientific significance for humanity's knowledge of cosmic origins and is based on detailed analysis of JWST data, providing substantial context and substance.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers may have spotted the universe’s first stars near us
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The very first stars in the universe, called Population III stars, are thought to have formed from simple gases like hydrogen and helium shortly after the Big Bang. These stars are usually too far away and old to see directly.

**What happened** – Scientists studied data from the James Webb Space Telescope, focusing on a distant galaxy named LAP1-B, seen as it was 800 million years after the Big Bang. This galaxy’s light was magnified by a closer galaxy cluster, making it possible to observe. Researchers found signs that LAP1-B contains a cluster of Population III stars, matching predictions about their size and brightness.

**Impact** – This could be the first time anyone has identified these ancient stars, which are different from stars we see today because they formed before heavier elements existed. Finding Population III stars helps us understand how the universe’s first heavy elements were created, which eventually led to everything we see around us.

**What’s next step** – More detailed observations and computer simulations are needed to confirm if LAP1-B really holds Population III stars. Scientists will keep searching other distant galaxies to find more examples and better understand these early stars.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time, astronomers may have found a cluster of the universe’s very first stars, opening a new window on how the cosmos began to change after the Big Bang.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes pourraient avoir détecté les toutes premières étoiles de l’univers près de nous
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les toutes premières étoiles de l’univers, appelées étoiles de Population III, se sont formées à partir de gaz simples comme l’hydrogène et l’hélium peu après le Big Bang. Ces étoiles sont généralement trop éloignées et anciennes pour être observées directement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des scientifiques ont étudié des données du télescope spatial James Webb, en se concentrant sur une galaxie lointaine nommée LAP1-B, vue telle qu’elle était il y a 800 millions d’années après le Big Bang. La lumière de cette galaxie a été amplifiée par un amas de galaxies plus proche, permettant son observation. Les chercheurs ont trouvé des indices montrant que LAP1-B contient un groupe d’étoiles de Population III, conforme aux prédictions sur leur taille et luminosité.

**Impact** – Cela pourrait être la première fois que ces étoiles anciennes sont identifiées. Ces étoiles sont différentes des étoiles actuelles car elles se sont formées avant l’apparition des éléments lourds. Trouver des étoiles de Population III aide à comprendre comment les premiers éléments lourds de l’univers ont été créés, ce qui a permis l’apparition de tout ce que nous connaissons.

**Prochaine étape** – Des observations plus précises et des simulations informatiques sont nécessaires pour confirmer si LAP1-B contient vraiment des étoiles de Population III. Les scientifiques continueront à chercher dans d’autres galaxies lointaines pour trouver plus d’exemples et mieux comprendre ces étoiles anciennes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Pour la première fois, les astronomes pourraient avoir trouvé un groupe des toutes premières étoiles de l’univers, ouvrant une nouvelle voie pour comprendre l’évolution du cosmos après le Big Bang.
articles.personality_title_es: Los astrónomos podrían haber encontrado las primeras estrellas del universo cerca de nosotros
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las primeras estrellas del universo, llamadas estrellas de Población III, se formaron a partir de gases simples como hidrógeno y helio poco después del Big Bang. Estas estrellas suelen estar demasiado lejos y ser demasiado antiguas para ser vistas directamente.

**Qué pasó** – Científicos analizaron datos del telescopio espacial James Webb, enfocándose en una galaxia lejana llamada LAP1-B, vista como era hace 800 millones de años después del Big Bang. La luz de esta galaxia fue ampliada por un cúmulo de galaxias más cercano, lo que permitió su observación. Los investigadores encontraron indicios de que LAP1-B contiene un grupo de estrellas de Población III, coincidiendo con las predicciones sobre su tamaño y brillo.

**Impacto** – Esta podría ser la primera vez que se identifican estas estrellas antiguas, que son diferentes de las estrellas actuales porque se formaron antes de que existieran elementos más pesados. Encontrar estrellas de Población III ayuda a entender cómo se crearon los primeros elementos pesados del universo, lo que llevó a todo lo que vemos hoy.

**Próximo paso** – Se necesitan observaciones más detalladas y simulaciones por computadora para confirmar si LAP1-B realmente contiene estrellas de Población III. Los científicos seguirán buscando en otras galaxias lejanas para encontrar más ejemplos y comprender mejor estas estrellas tempranas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Por primera vez, los astrónomos podrían haber encontrado un grupo de las primeras estrellas del universo, abriendo una nueva ventana para entender cómo cambió el cosmos tras el Big Bang.
